course.subject: LIFS
course.name: Biochemical Laboratory Techniques
course.description: Principles of biochemical techniques including spectrophotometry, column chromatography, electrophoresis, metabolite assay, enzyme assay, nucleic acid isolation and protein isolation.

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: Good Introductory Course to BCB
reviews.comment_content:
The content for this course is composed of 8 chapters with 10-15 slides in each chapter's ppt. For Fall Semester 2021-2022, LIFS2820(1 credit) is a GRADED course.‼️

Lecture 1- Buffers Titrations and pH measurement
Lecture 2- Chromatography I
Lecture 3- Gel Filtration
Lecture 4- Gel electrophoresis
Lecture 5- Enzyme Kinetics and Spectro
Lecture 6- Centrifugation and Marker Enzyme Assay
Lecture 7- Metabolic Syndrome I
Lecture 8- Metabolic Syndrome II

There will be 1 lecture lasting around 50 mins per week. The lecture and lab session will actually start after the end of the add-drop periods and ends 2 weeks before the final examination period. So ther course arrangement is quit good and flexible.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can say Dr. Lam has his unique way of teaching. He tends to draw our attention by giving us hints of what we are expected to see and to be examined in the final exam during his lecturing time. He will explicitly mention which part that we need to focus more on and will certainly appear in his exam for LIFS2820. So paying full attention during his lecture is the first step to getting a good grade and acquiring unique exam tips from him.
reviews.comment_grading:
For grading, I would like to share some exam tips here.
In the final exam for LIFS2820, this years' final had 64 MCQs in total. And tips are:


-find the pH of water at 70c with pKa of ionization of water given
-definition of buffer capacity
-The Henderson-Hasselbelch Equation
-the concept of at pKa=pH(half-equivalent point), [Conjugate base]=[acid]
-the concept of gel electrophoresis and the principal (V0,Vi,Vt)
-Anion and cation exchange chromatography and exchangers
-electrophoretic mobility determinant
-Centrifugal Rotors and their application
-the difference between Isopycnic and Rate Zonal Centrifugation
-Function of steroids and cholesterol ( it is NOT made in the pancreas)
-LDL and HDL
-the function of IgM

Letter Grade: A+ ( Final exam scores not released)
These are tips that you will definitely find useful in the final exam. Wish you guys good luck!
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty light, only 50 mins of lecture per week.

8 lectures in total for this 1 credit course across the whole fall semester.

Revise a day and a half before the exam is enough to get a good grade

reviews.author: isaachkchang
reviews.title: Lecture session for Biochemical Laboratory. Final is tough
reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course has already been covered many times in other courses(eg. LIFS 1902, LIFS 2210, LIFS 2040...) There is hardly anything new which makes this lecture session quite boring and useless. Although the name for the course may lead you to think that it will focus on laboratory techniques like how to work with a pipetman, centrifuge and so on, it mainly talks about the theory and principles behind the experiments. Basically, it is no different than a lecture covering the biological concepts used in the experiments.

Lecture 1- Buffers Titrations and pH measurement
Lecture 2- Chromatography I
Lecture 3- Chromatography II
Lecture 4- Chromatography III
Lecture 5- Spectrophotometry
Lecture 6- Organelle Isolation by Centrifugation and Marker Enzyme Assay
Lecture 7- DNA melting
Lecture 8- Metabolic Syndrome I
Lecture 9- Metabolic Syndrome II
reviews.comment_teaching:
Robert Ko is a chill dude. He always wears his lab coat( with his lab logo) to class. Because the lecture is around lunchtime, lots of people bring food to the lecture, but he doesn't really mind.

Again, the materials of this course is extremely fundamental and basic. It is almost impossible to make the lecture interesting. However, Robert does manage to make the lecture somewhat bearable with his occasional jokes.

He is quite long-winded but I guess that means you won't miss anything if you nod off for a second.

(Funny thing: Robert Ko was away for one lecture and Dr. Phillip Lam came in to substitute. He asked the class "Does Robert really talk for the entire lecture time?" To which the class replied yes.  )
reviews.comment_grading:
Harsh grading.

I calculated the mean and SD myself.

Total number of people taking the final exam: 99

Mean: 53.4/80
Sd: 8.66/80
Max: 71/80

I got 64/80 which put me 1.27 SD above mean. I ranked 8th(7 people got higher than 64) and tied with 4 people. I got A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignments at all. The only assessment is the final exam.

A very important note about the final exam. Be sure to memorize every single detail on the powerpoint slides. Pay particular attention to the reagents mentioned in the powerpoint slides(eg. common staining dyes, supporting medium in gel electrophoresis, particular wavelengths used for measurement...). Although this is only a 1-credit course, the questions go quite in-depth which may catch people off guard.

Format of final exam is as attached.

reviews.author: ggg_
reviews.comment_content: This is the lecture session that goes with LIFS2720(lab). There are 8 labs in total this semester, covering buffer, titration and pH measurement, ion-exchange chromatography, gel-filtration chromatography, protein gel-electrophoresis, spectrophotometry, centrifugation, marker enzyme assay, and metabolic syndrome of glucose and lipids. The principles of each experimental techniques and methods are introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor explains the concepts and principles quite clearly. However, you need to listen very carefully and jot down notes quickly as no recordings are available.
reviews.comment_grading: One final exam counts 100% for the grading. This course seems to be well-known for bad grading. I also heard that the A range is rather small, but no statistics are given. Thankfully it is only a 1 credit course. The principles and applications of the techniques are tested. He didn't provide sample questions or tell us the type of questions, but I found one document under other reviews that give sample questions for each question type. That is definitely helpful because the question types are exactly the same and it will give you an idea about what to prepare. The time for final exam is quite tight as some questions are tricky. No short and long questions. (LIFS2720 are mainly short and long questions, asking you to write out the procedure of a chromatograhy experiment, proceed the data from experiment, purpose of each step of an experiment, things you need to pay attention to when using the pipetman etc. The time is also quite tight, don't just read the first questions and think it is easy to finish)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is ok. Attend the lectures as no recordings are released and you need the professor's explanation to understand figures. He will also mention which part is important and may appear in the exam. Try your best to remember every details on the slides and what he said is important to better prepare for the exam.

reviews.author: mc_cch
reviews.title: Basic Biochemistry Experiments
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces fundamental concepts of biochemistry experiments. Topics include pH measurement, buffers, chromatography, electrophoresis, enzyme and metabolism, etc.
You can get a taste of doing real lab research (like that in FYP)
reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. LAM is definitely one of the best professors I have met at UST. He is very patient and explained the concept in detail. Moreover, he always gives us some tips about the final exam, so we can have a clearer direction when doing revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading (?)
Nobody knows how the exam is graded

Final Exam
reviews.comment_workload: You should spend enough time going through the lecture materials at least 1-2 days before the lab briefing. Pay attention to the unit conversion, the mechanism of each concept, and the main ideas emphasized by Dr. Lam.

reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 1- Buffers Titrations and pH measurement
Lecture 2- Chromatography I

Lecture 5- Enzyme Kinetics and Spectrometry

Although the grading is not that good as I think, but overall did learn something from it and the topics are quite interesting and practical
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Lam is very nice, he explained the concept very well, and he is always willing to answer students' questions. However, you may need to pay attention in class and jot down notes too since the professor wont upload any lecture recordings but only just the powerpoint slides.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading scheme of the course is 100% final and the final exam is quite tricky and hard I would say. There is no mark reveal and grade was directly released
reviews.comment_workload: Revision is required, better understand the concept after each lecture and lab although it is a 1 credit course
